titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Anne Harney

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T20:23-0400

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Herbert Friedman was born in Brooklyn, New York and graduated from Brooklyn College in 1936 (BS) and from Johns Hopkins (Phd, Physics). He joined the Naval Research Laboratory in 1940, and until about 1950 maintained an active research program in applied x-ray spectroscopy. In 1949 he conducted his first of many space experiments comprising a set of x-ray and ultraviolet sensitive geiger counters to observe the Sun.

Friedman is recognized as one of the pioneers of space science for his contributions to solar physics, upper atmospheric physics and x-ray astronomy. He was also recognized as one of the great statesman of the discipline having been a member of the President's Science Advisory Committee, the General Advisory Committee to the Atomic Energy Commission, the Space Science Board of the National Academy of Sciences, the Governing Board of the National Academy of Sciences. His awards include the Eddington Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society, the National Medal of Science, the William Bowie Medal of the American Geophysical Society, the Henry Norris Russell Award of the American Astronomical Society and the Wolf Foundation Prize in Physics. He was elected a member of the National Academy of Science in 1960. He retired from the Naval Research Laboratory in 1980 but continued an association with the Laboratory as a consultant and as Chief Scientist, emeritus.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access to Series XIV - Restricted Nominations and Personnel Files has been restricted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series I consists of Dr. Friedman’s personal correspondence. It is organized alphabetically with the bulk placed in miscellaneous files. The largest file consists of correspondence with Edward O. Hulburt, Dr. Friedman’s mentor and namesake of the Edward O. Hulburt Center for Space Research at the Navy Research Laboratory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence received on the occasion of Dr. Friedman's 60th and 80th birthdays.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes Ground Station Manuals that were enclosed with correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two letters regarding Dr. Friedman's election as a Knight of Mark Twain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This letter from President Nixon to Dr. Friedman accepts Dr. Friedman's resignation as Chief Scientist of the E. O. Hulburt Center for Space Research under the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. It also informs Dr. Friedman that President Nixon plans to reorganize and thus disband the President's Science Advisory Committee.

did.unittitle: Series II. Research Materials and Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series II is comprised of Dr. Friedman’s research material from his time at the Navy Research Laboratory. It consists mainly of diagrams and charts of experiments, as well as some research notebooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series III consists of manuscripts and printed copies of Dr. Friedman’s works. Included are articles for journals and magazines, as well as book manuscripts, including The Amazing Universe, The Sun and Earth and The Astronomer’s Universe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series IV, the second largest in the collection, consists of correspondence, official reports and papers from Dr. Friedman’s career at the Navy Research Laboratory. The series includes work from scientists that Dr. Friedman worked with and supervised, including Dr. Talbot A. Chubb and Dr. George R. Carruthers. The correspondence is organized chronologically, as names are rarely used; internal code numbers are used instead. Dr. Friedman was, for some time, Code 7100, but used other designations as well. Signatures on memos and letters are best consulted to be sure of the author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series V is made up of materials regarding the patents applied for, and awarded to Dr. Friedman during his time at the Navy Research Laboratory. In his lifetime Dr. Friedman was awarded 50 patents, all of which are reflected here in some manner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VI contains works by others, including some his co-workers at the Navy Research Laboratory. Prominently featured are the works of Talbot A. Chubb, George R. Carruthers, Irving Blifford and Riccardo Giacconi, co-recipient of the 2002 Nobel Prize for Physics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This two-page undated narrative fragment, whose author is unknown, describes an experiment which observed solar x-rays covering an eleven-year solar cycle. The author comments that this experiment's results were published in Nature, and the results were put in question by James Warwick and Harold Zirin.

did.unittitle: Present Status of Long Baseline Optical Interferometry
Significance of New Tubes Originated By Herbert Friedman for Radiac Instruments

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This untitled manuscript spans 120 pages. The only "title" it seems to have is a notation at the top: ICSU-IGBP - Tape 1, Side A, August 6, 1984. It seems to set forth a theory regarding climate change and tectonic plate movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This partial manuscript spans seven pages. At the bottom is superscript that states "Chapter 9 -- Sun and Earth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains correspondence between Dr. Friedman and various scientists (including Freeman Dyson) on the publication of a book on Joseph Shklovsky, also known as Iosif Shklovsky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VII, the largest in the collection, consists of correspondence, administrative and report material from Dr. Friedman’s membership in various professional and private organizations. The series highlights the prominent role Dr. Friedman played in many organizations, including the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, the American Philosophical Society, the Cosmos Club, the National Academy of Sciences, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, as well as the National Research Council. Correspondence in the series is organized as Dr. Friedman’s original files were, by date.

This folder contains some correspondence relating to the symposium. The symposium was held on May 24, 1976, at the National Academy of Sciences in Washingon, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VIII contains the many certificates and awards bestowed to Dr. Friedman during his lifetime, as well as related correspondence and announcements. Among Dr. Friedman’s awards that the series contains are the Eddington Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society, the National Medal of Science, the Henry Norris Russell Lectureship of the American Astronomical Society, the William Bowie Medal of the American Geophysical Union, and the Wolf Foundation Prize in Physics. Some material has been removed to oversize.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The personal material contained in Series IX includes passports, biographical and curriculum vitae material, as well as material related to Dr. Friedman’s retirement from the Navy Research Laboratory. Also included is obituary and memorial material, including material relating the dedication of the Herbert Friedman Room at the Navy Research Laboratory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains various drafts of biographical sketches from various publishers, including Who's Who in America and American Men and Women of Science.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder includes Herbert Friedman's materials and correspondence that nominated Edward O. Hulburt for the Nationa Academy of Sciences' John Adam Fleming Award and his condolences upon learning of Mrs. Hulburt's passing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains an impressive and clearly drawn family tree of the Friedman family, going back to 1737.

scopecontent.p: This folder contains programs of memorials and services which remember Dr. Friedman and his outstanding contributions to science.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series X, the printed materials series, consists of published works and reprints authored mainly by others, but also including work by Dr. Friedman himself. NASA manuals regarding shuttle payload development feature prominently.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series XI contains photos and images of Dr. Friedman, as well as figures from his published works and printed slides from various lectures and presentations. While few of the photos are personal snapshots, they do include photos removed from various correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This album contains large black and white photos showing Dr. Friedman's time in the Fiji Islands during a rocket experiment. Photographs of the experiment, including its launching, are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In addition to forty-four loose photos of Dr. Friedman, this folder also contains two envelopes: one large and one small. The large manila envelope contains photos of a Chinese delegation, with Dr. Friedman showing them around. The second smaller envelope shows Dr. Friedman's attendance at a COSPAR convention in Leningrad, 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains large black and white photos of Dr. Friedman at various formal functions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains reprints of scientific articles in German, published by Philips Research Laboratories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains photos of Dr. Friedman and his wife, Gertrude, meeting Pope Paul VI. A small piece of realia, Dr. Friedman's name tag, made of leather, is included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains page-length photos in color or black and white of Dr. Friedman's many experiments and photographs of the sun or nebula. Some are quite breathtaking.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: Some of these should be re-sleeved into more appropriate encasings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Among these six items are three manila envelopes. One manila envelope contains photos from an event where a Chinese delegation visited the E.O. Hulburt Center for Space Science. Another manila envelope contains Dr. Friedman's original sketches for the Hulburt Center's holiday greeting cards for 1965. The third manila envelope contains a layout plan for a space center at the University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains two manila envelopes. One contains photos from the dedication ceremony of the E.O. Hulburt Center for Space Science; the other contains large portrait photos of Dr. Friedman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains photos of Dr. Friedman's many experiments, instrument readings, of Dr. Friedman himself and his colleagues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series XII contains audio visual material, including VHS tapes, film reels and slides. Many relate to Dr. Friedman’s work with NASA and the Navy Research Lab, as well as the National Academy of Sciences sponsored PBS Series Space Age, which Dr. Friedman participated in.

did.unittitle: Series XIII. Jon Friedman Art Notebooks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sketch of Albert Einstein was done most likely by Jon Friedman, Dr. Herbert Friedman's son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sketchbook contains a letter, dated April 1, 1991, from Robert A. Kolodny to Dr. Herbert Friedman. Professor Kolodny includes a photocopy of a sketch of Hyman Siegel by Herbert Friedman during the 1930s. Hyman Siegel was Professor Kolodny's grandfather; Mr. Siegel had taught a young Herbert Friedman bar mitzvah lessons.

scopecontent.p: Access to this series has been restricted.
